entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 13 at 3:11PM ChST until March 14 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 10 to 12 feet and minor coastal flooding.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Majuro.
* WHEN...Through 3 PM ChST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf is expected to slowly decrease through the rest of week. First dropping below 12 feet along north facing reefs, and then along east reefs and this is expected to occur around Thursday afternoon. The risk for coastal flooding is also decreasing as the peak of the King Tide has past.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Majuro

entry.title: Freeze Warning issued March 12 at 9:50PM PDT until March 13 at 9:00AM PDT by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Freeze Warning, sub-freezing temperatures as low as 32 expected. For the Wind Advisory, northeast winds 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 45 mph expected.
* WHERE...Northern Lake.
* WHEN...For the Freeze Warning, from 1 AM to 9 AM PDT Wednesday. For the Wind Advisory, from 11 PM Wednesday to 11 AM PDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor plumbing. Wind gusts will be particularly strong along windward ridges and exposed coastal headlands.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Lake County

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 12 at 11:40PM CDT until March 13 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Dodge City KS
entry.summary:
...Wildfire Danger Expected Near the Oklahoma Border Wednesday Afternoon...
The National Weather Service in Dodge City has issued a Red Flag Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from 1 PM to 7 PM CDT Wednesday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 087 Meade, Fire Weather Zone 088 Clark and Fire Weather Zone 089 Comanche.
* WINDS...Southwest 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any ignitions will have the potential to burn out of control quickly. Fire danger is expected to be highest immediately adjacent to the Oklahoma border, with fire danger increasing greatly south of the Kansas/Oklahoma state line. The strongest southwest winds are expected to remain over the Texas Panhandle into northwest Oklahoma.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Meade; Clark; Comanche

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 1 PM TO 7 PM CDT WEDNESDAY FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY

entry.summary:

* WHEN...Until 400 AM CDT.

This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 12 at 9:23PM EDT until March 13 at 1:00PM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Connecticut...Rhode Island...
Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County.
Connecticut River At Hartford affecting Middlesex and Hartford Counties.
Pawcatuck River At Wood River Junction affecting Washington County.
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Massachusetts...Rhode Island...Connecticut...
Taunton River Near Bridgewater affecting Bristol and Plymouth Counties.
Pawcatuck River At Westerly affecting New London and Washington Counties.
For the Connecticut River...including Montague, Northampton, Holyoke Dam, Holyoke, Springfield, Thompsonville, Hartford, Middle Haddam... Minor flooding is forecast. For the Pawcatuck River...including Wood River Junction, Westerly... Minor flooding is forecast. For the Taunton River...including Bridgewater...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Connecticut River at Hartford.
* WHEN...Until early tomorrow afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 17.0 feet, Lowland flooding is expected along the Connecticut River from Hartford through Wethersfield and Glastonbury, primarily outside of levee protection. This will affect several riverside roadways as well as several park and recreational facilities. Further downstream flooding is expected in low lying sections along the Connecticut River from Wethersfield and Glastonbury downstream through Cromwell, Middletown and Portland.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 PM EDT Tuesday the stage was 17.1 feet. - Bankfull stage is 16.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:45 PM EDT Tuesday was 18.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage tomorrow morning and continue falling to 12.1 feet Friday evening. - Flood stage is 16.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 12 at 8:33PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Charlotteville affecting Montgomery, Jeff Davis and Toombs Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Wednesday evening at 845 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Altamaha River at Charlotteville.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS... At 14.0 feet, Minor flooding continues in the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water covers the low portion and entrance of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. The public boat ramp is under two feet of water. Flood waters expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 16.0 feet, Minor flooding expands into the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. Flood waters continue to expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be 2 to 4 feet over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 18.0 feet, Minor flooding expands further into the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters will completely cover Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge and begin to flood the slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flood waters expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be 4 to 6 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane... Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 19.0 feet, Minor flooding expands upstream and downstream from the Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters near 3 feet deep cover Towns Bluff Lane and flood the slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flooding expands further into Montgomery County with the water 5 to 7 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. The water reaches the top of boat ramps and parking lots will begin to flood in Towns Bluff Park and along the end of Uvalda Landing Road in Jeff Davis County. At 20.0 feet, Moderate flooding begins. Significant flooding occurs upstream and downstream from the Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters will be near 4 feet deep on Towns Bluff Lane and flood the concrete slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flooding expands further into Montgomery county with the water 6 to 8 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. The parking lot at Towns Bluff Park and portions of Uvalda Landing Road will be flooded in Jeff Davis County.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:45 PM EDT Tuesday the stage was 15.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 18.9 feet Sunday evening. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 4:11PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Mid range computer models are coming into agreement about a moderate to heavy rain event for the middle of the week. The initial surge of moisture will move over the panhandle on Wednesday followed by more moisture Wednesday night and Thursday. Each will bring periods of moderate to heavy precip to the area, with the heaviest rates expected Wednesday night into Thursday. Current 24 hour precipitation totals for the panhandle from Wednesday morning through Thursday morning range from 1 to 2.5 inches, with the highest totals along the outer coast and southern panhandle. By the end of the work week, the plume of moisture directed over more southerly locations will shift northward, bringing another round of moderate to heavy precipitation.
In addition to the heavy precip, another concern is a significantly warmer low level airmass that is projected to move over the panhandle. This warmer air may result in snow levels rising to more than 4000 feet across the southern panhandle and from 2000 to 3500 feet over the northern panhandle by next weekend. Snowmelt at higher elevations will add to the heavy precipitation near sea level that may result in flooding along creeks, streams, and rivers. Ponding in areas with poor or blocked drainage may also become an issue.
We will continue to monitor this potential hazardous situation.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Sitka; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; City of Hyder; Annette Island

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 12 at 4:40PM PDT until March 13 at 12:05AM PDT by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Washington...
Skokomish River At Potlatch affecting Mason County.
.Heavy rainfall on Monday pushed the Skokomish River just above minor flood stage. Scattered showers will continue through the rest of today, but are not expected to be hydrologically impactful. The river is expected to drop back below flood late Tuesday afternoon.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Skokomish River at Potlatch.
* WHEN...Until just after midnight tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 16.5 feet, the Skokomish River will cause widespread flooding of pasture lands, with water flowing quickly over West Bourgault Road and Skokomish Valley Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:30 PM PDT Tuesday the stage was 16.5 feet. - Flood stage is 16.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 4:30 PM PDT Tuesday was 16.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late this afternoon and continue falling to 14.1 feet late Sunday morning. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.5 feet on 10/04/1997. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mason, WA

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 3:58PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
A vigorous low pressure system will drop into Arizona Thursday into Friday with a strong surface cold front sliding down the eastern plains. Windy conditions will develop quickly Thursday night into Friday as the cold front surges westward and accelerates through the gaps of the central mountain chain. This will create potentially damaging wind gusts up to 65 mph in east Albuquerque, especially near the base of Tijeras Canyon. Winds will remain strong and gusty through the day Friday and into Friday evening before tapering off by Saturday morning. Gusts will not be quite as strong in western areas of the Albuquerque metro area, but will still be gusty.
Residents and travelers should closely monitor the forecast for updates in the coming days, and make preparations to store loose items such as lawn furniture, trampolines and other items that might become airborne in the strong winds. Monitor NOAA weather radio, weather.gov/abq or your local media for the latest weather updates.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Middle Rio Grande Valley/Albuquerque Metro Area

cap:parameter.value: STRONG TO POTENTIALLY DAMAGING WINDS EXPECTED IN EASTERN ALBUQUERQUE

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 12 at 3:25PM MDT until March 13 at 7:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING WEDNESDAY NOON TO 7 PM FOR THE EAST CENTRAL PLAINS DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Strengthening flow aloft ahead of a powerful storm system, and an area of surface low pressure near the southeast corner of Colorado, will produce strong southwest winds over the east central plains Wednesday afternoon until sunset. Humidities will also plummet near and below 15 percent as high temperatures climb a few to around 10 degrees above normal.
* AREA AND TIMING...East Central Plains (Zone 126) Wednesday from noon to 7 PM MDT.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...West 20 to 35 mph with gusts up to 45 mph, except up to 50 mph on the Caprock.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Dropping between 11 and 18 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Central Plains

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 12 at 2:06PM CDT until March 13 at 10:00PM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM CDT /7 AM MDT/ TO 10 PM CDT /9 PM MDT/ WEDNESDAY FOR FOR RELATIVE HUMIDITY OF 15% OR LESS, 20-FT WINDS OF 20 MPH OR MORE, AND HIGH TO VERY HIGH FIRE DANGER FOR THE GUADALUPE, DELAWARE, AND DAVIS MOUNTAINS, DAVIS MOUNTAIN FOOTHILLS, MARFA PLATEAU, SOUTHEAST NEW MEXICO, REEVES COUNTY, AND CULBERSON COUNTY PLAINS, CENTRAL AND NORTHERN PERMIAN BASIN, AND MOST OF THE WESTERN LOW ROLLING PLAINS...
* AFFECTED AREA...Gaines, Dawson, Borden, Scurry, Andrews, Martin, Howard, Loving, Winkler, Ector, Midland, Sacramento Foothills and Guadalupe Mountains, Chaves Plains, Eddy Plains, Lea, Guadalupe and Delaware Mountains, Van Horn and Highway 54 Corridor, Eastern Culberson County, Reeves County Plains, Davis Mountains and Davis Mountains Foothills.
* TIMING...From 8 AM CDT /7 AM MDT/ to 10 PM CDT /9 PM MDT/ Wednesday.
* WINDS...West 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 55 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 10 percent.
* RFTI...4 or near critical.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 9:04AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
Northeast winds of 15 mph gusting to 30 mph over Steese, Elliot and Dalton Highway Summits will continue into tonight. This is causing blowing and drifting snow and wind chills to 35 below over summits. Snow drifts could make travel difficult over summits.
People traveling over summits of the Steese, Elliott and Dalton Highways north of the Chatanika River should be prepared for severe winter conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dalton Highway Summits; White Mountains and High Terrain South of the Yukon River
